newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Environment Council concludes long agenda.
newsitem.headline: Environment Council concludes long agenda.

text.p: European environment ministers completed a long environment council agenda in the early hours of Tuesday morning, boasting a common position and a political agreement for their efforts but failing to secure a deal on climate change.
Ministers' common position was for the European Commission's proposal for a review of the Community's Fifth Action Programme on environment and sustainable development.
The compromise altered references to agriculture and access to justice, according to a Commission spokesman.
"A common position was reached by the skin of the Council's teeth," the spokesman told reporters.

"It was by unanimous common position. The Commission criticised a watering down of the text on integration of the environment into agriculture policies and on access to justice," he said, adding that the Council had not discussed any of the European Parliament's amendments to COM(95)647.
The proposal attracted parliamentarians' anger last month, when some of them described it as ineffectual and unambitious when they debated it in Strasbourg.
Environment Euro-MPs said that with the EU likely to miss many of its 2000 targets for environmental improvement, more should be done.

Ministers failed to reach a deal on climate change and issued a threat to impose their long-delayed import ban on fur from animals caught in leg-hold traps against exporters in Canada, Russia and the United States.

Council reached political agreement on the Commission's proposal for amending Directive 90/219 on the contained use of genetically modified micro-organisms (GMMs), which was presented in March 1996 under article 130s(1).
Council also agreed its resolution on Commission proposal COM(96)399 to modify the EU's waste management strategy.

The main issues are the waste hierarchy -- re-use, recycle, dispose -- with the ministers' attention being on the definition of recycling as it refers to incineration with or without energy recovery versus material recycling.

Ministers also adopted conclusions on next year's United Nations General Assembly Special Session (UNGASS), a follow-up to the Rio conference of 1992, and heard reports from the Irish presidency on what has happened under their tenure with the Auto/Oil proposals, COM(96)248, and with the draft drinking water directive COM(94)612.

Ministers also discussed two other waste items concerning a spin-off proposal to Regulation 259/93 on control procedures for waste exports of non-hazardous wastes destined for non-OECD countries and final adoption of the proposed amendments to the 1993 regulation itself.
Ministers also heard a report on the Commission proposal for promoting non-governmental organisations working on environment issues although they will not discuss it, officials said.

Ministers also raced through a long list of any-other-business items, including a Commission review of efforts related to the recent accession of countries' environmental derogations, a presidency report on the third conference of the parties to the Convention on Biological Diversity, a report on the eighth Montreal Protocol meeting, a British report on efforts to cut ground-level ozone and to combat environment crimes, and a Swedish delegation report on Agenda 21 measures for the Baltic Sea region.
